title: Essential Mathematical Methods
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1028, 1050/1058 or students who are taking MATH1525 in the same term. Co-requisite: MATH1010/1018.
description: This course is designed as a continuation of the HKDSE Mathematics (Compulsory Part) or equivalent, to familiarize mathematics major students with elementary and foundational algebraic and geometric methods which will help the study of other MATH courses.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are able to:  Understand the content of simple mathematical statements.  Apply various results about elementary algebraic methods and geometric methods in simple computational type problems.  Deduce, with reference of definitions, (but if relevant and necessary, with various established classical results assumed) simple mathematical results in elementary algebra, such as divisibility (for integers), inequalities (about real numbers), complex numbers, polynomials and their roots.  Read off and describe solutions of simple equations and inequalities through the use of algebraic methods, and/or graphical methods. Handle simple geometric problems with algebraic methods, and visualize simple algebraic problems through geometry.
syllabus: Summation and product notations, set notations (including the description of sets through specification), divisibility for integers, rationals and irrationals, surds, laws of indices, inequalities about real numbers, absolute value, algebra of complex numbers and the Argand plane, polynomials and their roots, Binomial Theorem, solving (algebraic-type) equations and inequalities (with elementary algebraic means), classical inequalities, simple infinite sequences and series,  exponentiation and logarithm, trigonometric functions, coordinate geometry in two/three dimensions, vector geometry in two/three dimensions, basic methods of mathematical argument (such as direct proof, mathematical induction, proof-by-contradiction argument, dis-proof) through concrete examples.
recommended_readings: K. T. Leung, P. H. Cheung: Fundamental Concepts of Mathematics. K. T. Leung, I. A. C. Mok, S. N. Suen: Polynomials and Equations. K. T. Leung, S. N. Suen: Vectors, Matrices and Geometry. William Briggs, G. H. Bryan: The Tutorial Algebra (Volumes I, II). S. L. Green: Advanced Level Pure Mathematics.

title: Methods of Matrices and Linear Algebra
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1030/1038.
description: This course is intended as an introduction to elementary linear algebra through a matrix oriented approach. The course is suitable for students without much mathematics background and intended to be major in Statistics, Economics, Business, Life Sciences and Social Sciences.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to  - Perform essential calculations in matrices, determinants, and linear systems; - Use these calculations in the context of certain business and scientific applications; - Realize the importance of linear algebra in a broad spectrum of subject areas; - Prepare for undergraduate studies requiring statistical knowledge.
syllabus: Matrix and vector notations, systems of linear equations and Gaussian elimination, linear independence of row/column vectors; matrix operations and inverse, cofactor expansion and properties of determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, orthogonal vectors and Gram-Schmidt process, orthogonal projection and least-square method, subspaces in Euclidean space, basis and dimension, matrix transformations.

title: Numerical Analysis
description: Floating-point numbers and roundoff errors, absolute and relative errors, stable and unstable computations, solutions of nonlinear equations, linear systems, interpolation, numerical differentiation, and numerical integration. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra. They are also expected to have basic programming skills in some programming language (such as MATLAB, C++, Python).Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are expected to understand the fundamental concepts involved in numerical analysis, and learn some basic approaches and techniques in solving linear and nonlinear systems, constructing interpolations and do numerical differntiation and integration. The basic learning outcomes include: - Students understand the basic concepts in scientific computings, including fixed-point numbers, floating-point numbers, single and double precision, overflow and underflow, roundoff errors, absolute and relative errors, stable and unstable computations. - Students learn some basic knowledge in floating-point arithmetic and know how to use the backward error analysis to estimate possible errors generated in numerical computings. - Students learn some basic concepts in solving nonlinear equations of one variable: iterative methods, rate of convergence, local and global convergence; learn some classical methods for solving nonlinear equations of one variable: bisection methods, Newton's method, quasi-Newton's method and fixed-point iteration, and learn how to analyse convergence of these method. - Students learn some basic methods for solving linear system of equations: Cholesky factorization, LU and LDU factorization, forward- and backward-substitutions for traingular systems, Gaussian elimination. - Students learn sensitivity analysis of the solutions of linear systems with respect to some errors in their coefficient matrices or in their right-hand sides, and understand condition numbers and their importance. - Students learn three polynomial interpolations, Newton form of interpolations, Lagrange and spline interpolations, and learn how to estimate the interpolation errors. - Students learn some popular numerical integrations: trapezoidal and composite trapezoidal rules, Simpson and composite Simpson rules, Newton-Cotes quadrature rule, Gaussian quadrature rules, and learn how to estimate the errors of quadrature rules. - Students learn some basic numerical differentiation techniques: forward differences, backward differences, central differences, and understand how to estimate the errors of these difference schemes.
syllabus: Floating-point numbers and roundoff errors, absolute and relative errors, stable and unstable computations, solutions of nonlinear equations, linear systems, interpolation, numerical differentiation, numerical integration.
recommended_readings: Main Reference: - D. Kincaid & W. Cheney, Numerical Analysis: Mathematics of Scientific Computing, Brooks/Cole Publishing Co., New York - G.W. Stewart, Afternotes on Numerical Analysis, SIAM Other References: - R. L. Burden and J. D. Faires, Numerical Analysis, Brooks/Cole-Thomson Learning - C.F. Gerald and P.O. Wheatley, Applied Numerical Analysis, Person Addison Wesley - G.H. Golub and C.F. van Loan, Matrix computations, Johns Hopkins University Press, MD

title: Numerical Methods for Differential Equations
description: Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, numerical solution of partial differential equations. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra. They are also expected to have basic programming skills in some programming language (such as MATLAB, C++, Python).Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are expected to understand some fundamental concepts involved in numerical methods for differential equations, and learn some basic approaches and techniques in solving ordinary and partial differential equations. The basic learning outcomes include: - Students understand the importance of differential equations in modeling real-world phenomena and understand the meanings and importance of numerical methods in solving general ordinary and partial differential equations. - Students learn some basic mathematical method of verifying the well-posedness of a ordinary differential equation (ODE). - For a given first order ODE, students learn how to construct Taylor-series methods and Runge-Kutta methods with orders up to four. - Students learn some basic approaches to constructing multistep methods: the quadrature rule approach, test function approach by polynomials, Adams-Bashforth and Adams-Mouton methods. And learn how to solve ODEs using multistep methods and predictor-corrector methods. - Students learn how to compute the orders of multistep methods, and how to analyse consistency, stability and convergence of multistep methods and understand the relationship between these three concepts. - Students learn how to convert a higher order ODE into a system of first order ODEs and how to construct Taylor-series methods and Runge-Kutta methods for the resulting ODE system. - Students learn some important numerical methods for solving stiff ODEs, and understand the importance of A-stability, absolute stability and regions of absolute stability. - Students learn how to use the shooting method to transform a two-point boundary value problem into an initial value problem. - Students learn some basic finite difference schemes and collocation methods to solve two-point boundary value problems. - Students learn some basic finite difference schemes to solve the one- and two-dimensional parabolic equations, and know how to analyse the consistency, stability and convergence of a finite difference scheme. - Students learn some simple finite element methods to solve the one- and two-dimensional parabolic equations.
syllabus: Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, numerical solution of partial differential equations.

title: Ordinary Differential Equations

title: Mathematical Modeling
description: This course introduces the concept of mathematical modeling. Topics include: different modeling techniques such as modeling with differential equations and modeling with linear programming, forecasting; economic models such as Markov models, network models and financial models such as input-output models and scheduling models.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are expected to learn some basic techniques and mathematical tools to set up a mathematical model for a given real-world problem, and to be able to do simulations using a model and to know how to improve a model. The basic learning outcomes include:  - Students understand practical meanings and importance of mathematical modeling in various applications. - For a given real-world process, students learn how to identify the problem to be modeled by selecting only those most important and relevant factors. - For a given real-world process, students understand the basic procedures to set up a mathematical model. - Students learn modeling with discrete dynamical systems and difference equations to predict the future based on what is known at the present and the observed changes. - Students understand the concepts of long-time behaviors of solutions to a discrete dynamical system and their relation to equilibrium values of the system, and understand how to identify stability and instability of an equilibrium value. - Students learn how to analyses the sensitivity of a model to its initial conditions and model parameters. - For a given set of observed data, students learn how to formulate a model using the Chebyshev approximation criterion, the criterion of minimizing the sum of absolute deviations and the least-squares criterion. And understand the relations between the three criteria and learn some basic solution techniques to solve the resulting model systems. - For a given real-world process, students learn how to find an appropriate model after trying various types of model functions. - Students understand the advantages and disadvantages of polynomial models, and understand the smoothing effects by low-order polynomials. - Students learn how to simulate deterministic behaviors by Monte Carlo algorithms and probabilistic behaviors by probability models. - Students learn how to set up a discrete optimization model and solve linear programming models by simplex method. - Students learn modeling with differential equations, and know how to plot phase lines and sketch solution curves based on equilibrium solutions and signs of first and second derivatives. - Students learn how to apply the Lagrange multiplier method to solve constrained optimization problems.
syllabus: Topics include: different modeling techniques such as modeling with differential equations and modeling with linear programming, forecasting; economic models such as Markov models, network models and financial models such as input-output models and scheduling models.
recommended_readings: Main References: - F. Giordano, M. Weir and W. Fox, A First Course in Mathematical Modeling, Brooks/Cole Publishing Company, third edition Other References: - W.J. Meyer, Concepts of mathematical modeling, McGraw-Hill Book Company - R.Haberman, Mathematical Models, SIAM, Philadelphia - G. Lei, Mathematical Modeling, Peking University Press

title: Computational and Applied Mathematics
description: This course introduces the general solution methods used in computational and applied mathematics. The central topics are differential equations and matrix equations. Methods include Fourier series, orthogonal expansion, conformal mapping, Fourier integrals, complex integration, LU decomposition, Newton method, semi-direct and iterative methods, the finite element methods and fast Fourier transform. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Foundation of Data Analytics
description: This course gives an introduction to computational data analytics, with emphasis on its mathematical foundations. The goal is to carefully develop and explore mathematical theories and methods that make up the backbone of modern mathematical data sciences, such as knowledge discovery in databases, machine learning, and mathematical artificial intelligence. Topics include mathematical foundations of probability, linear approximation and its polynomial and high dimensional extensions, proper orthogonal decomposition methods, optimization, theories of nonlinear neural network and approximations. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge of basic linear algebra. They are also expected to have basic programming skills in some programming language (such as MATLAB, C++, Python).Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Learning outcomes:  On completion of this course, students will be able to: • Understand in-depth the various topics in modern data analysis and the technical difficulties in solving them • Acquire knowledge about the foundation of computational data analytics • Learn how to use various mathematical models to extract important information from big data  • Systematically evaluate the performance of different models to solve various data analysis problems • Understand the importance of computational data analytics for real-world problems
syllabus: Cover various topics related to computational data analytics, including mathematical foundations of probability, linear approximation and its polynomial and high dimensional extensions, proper orthogonal decomposition methods, optimization, theories of nonlinear neural network and approximations.
required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.

description: This course provides students with practical experience in using mathematical techniques for big data computing, numerical optimization and simulations of practical mathematical models through various programming and software implementation. syllabus: Cover mathematical techniques for big data computing, numerical optimization and simulations of practical mathematical models through various programming and software implementation.

title: Mathematics of Machine Learning
description: This course presents the fundamental mathematical theory for modern machine learning techniques, including empirical risk minimization (error decomposition, Rademacher complexity, covering number), optimization method (gradient descent and stochastic gradient descent), kernel methods, and deep neural networks (approximation theory and over-parameterization). Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2040/2048, MATH2050/2058 and MATH2060/2068, or equivalent. Familiarity with basic concepts about probability theory (e.g., knowledge in MATH3280), and basic programming skills in some programming language (such as MATLAB, C++, Python) will be helpful though not compulsory.
outcome: On completion of this course, students are able to understand some classical analysis techniques in statistical learning theory, and to familiarize the skills in learning theory.
syllabus: Linear regression, empirical risk optimization, gradient type optimization algorithms, kernel methods and deep neural networks

title: Mathematical Imaging
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH1030/1038 and MATH2010/2018.
description: This course gives an introduction on mathematical models and techniques for various image processing tasks. A wide array of topics will be covered, including image restoration (denoising, deblurring), image decomposition, image segmentation, image registration, feature detection, multi-scale image analysis, morphology and so on. Students will become familiar with essential mathematical techniques for imaging tasks, such as image processing in the spatial domain (using gradient, Laplacian, convolution) and frequency domain (using Fourier / wavelet transform). Variational models and PDE-based techniques will also be discussed.Students are expected to have basic knowledge in calculus and linear algebra. Some basic programming skills, such as Matlab, C++ or other programming languages, are also expected for programming exercises. Some background in numerical analysis, Fourier analysis and partial differential equations will be helpful, although the necessary concepts will be discussed as they are used. Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are expected to learn the basic digital image processing principles and concepts with emphasis on their mathematical aspects. Upon completion of the course, students are expected to: 1. learn the basic mathematical concepts and techniques for imaging problems; 2. be aware of the important role of mathematics in image processing; 3. appreciate the importance of image processing in the real world; 4. be able to implement (using MATLAB) mathematical models for various imaging tasks; 5. learn how to design simple imaging models for real-world problems.
syllabus: A wide array topics will be covered, including image restoration (denoising, deblurring), image decomposition, image segmentation, image registration, feature detection, multi-scale image analysis, morphology and so on.

title: Functional Analysis
requirements:
Pre-requisite: 
[Alternative 1] MATH3060
[Alternative 2] Grade B- or above in both MATH2050/2058 and MATH2060/2068.
description: Metric spaces, fixed point theorems, Banach spaces, Hilbert spaces, continuous linear operator, the Hahn-Banach extension theorem, the uniform boundedness principle and the open mapping theorem, and applications of the above topics. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis and linear algebra.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: This is an advanced undergraduate course. We expect students to understand how linear algebra and analysis can be put together to become one of the most important fields of mathematics; we also emphasize the generality and depth of this treatment as a useful tool in many other disciplines and for graduate study. - Students are expected to know the distance concept in metric spaces, and point set topology such as open sets and close sets, convergence, Cauchy sequences, completion, continuity. - Students learn the concept of norm linear spaces, Banach spaces, compactness of finite dimensional spaces, bounded linear operators, functionals and dual spaces. - Students learn inner product spaces, Hilbert spaces, orthogonality and direct sums. These concepts will be used in Fourier series and other classical orthogonal series. - Students learn the Reiesz representation theorem on Hilbert space and use it to define the adjoint operators. An elementary theory on self-adjoint operator will be developed. - Students learn the fundamental theorems for normed linear spaces: the Hahn-Banach theorem and its applications to the Reiesz representation theorem on continuous function space, the uniform boundedness principle, the open mapping theorem. The concept of strong and weak convergence will be introduced. - Students learn how to solve some standard differential equations in certain nice domains, like Laplace equation in a unit disk, by using the Fourier series. - Students learn how to construct a series of orthonormal polynomial functions by Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process. - Students learn how to find the Fourier and inverse Fourier transforms, as well as the discrete Fourier transform for a given function. - Students learn the LU factorization for a given matrix and its relation with Gaussian elimination. - Students learn how to solve nonlinear systems of equations by Newton's method, and how to solve linear systems of equations by Jacobi, Gauss-Seidal and successive overrelaxation methods, and understand why these methods work or do not work for some linear or nonlinear systems. - Students learn how to find the eigenvalues of a matrix by QR factorization and understand the mathematics behind. - Students learn the fast Fourier transform and its applications. - Students learn how to solve a two-point boundary value problem by a simple finite element method.
syllabus: Metric spaces, fixed point theorems, Banach spaces, Hilbert spaces, continuous linear operator, the Hahn-Banach extension theorem, the uniform boundedness principle and the open mapping theorem, and applications of the above topics. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis and linear algebra.
recommended_readings: Main References: - Introduction to Functional Analysis with Applications, E. Kreysgiz, Wiley Other References: - Introduction to Topology and Modern Analysis, G.F. Simons, McGraw-Hill - Real Analysis, H. Royden, Macmillian - Real and Complex Analysis, W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill - Functional Analysis, W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill

title: Calculus of Variations
description: This course is intended to provide a basic theory of calculus of variations. Topics are usually selected from: necessary condition for extremum, Euler equation, fixed end point problem for unknown functions involving higher-order derivatives, natural boundary condition and transversality, Weierstrass-Erdman corner conditions, and sufficient conditions. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Differential Geometry
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH4033.
description: This course covers basic theory on curves, and surfaces in the Euclidean three space. Topics include: regular curves, Frenet formulas, local theory of curves, global properties of curves such as isoperimetric inequality, regular surfaces, 1st and 2nd fundamental form, Gaussian curvature and mean curvature, Gauss map, special surfaces such as ruled surfaces, surfaces of revolution, minimal surfaces, intrinsic geometry: geodesic, and Gauss-Bonnet Theorem. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus, linear algebra, and elementary differential equations.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: - Students learn ways to describe curves and surfaces in space, by equations and parametrizations. - Students learn the differential approach to regular geometric objects, using moving frames and searching for complete local invariants. In particular, they learn the Frenet frame, curvature and torsion of regular space curves. - Students use integration techniques to study some global theorems on plane curves and methods of ordinary differential equations to obtain curves with prescribed curvature and torsion. - Students learn the formulation of regular surfaces in 3 dimensions, their orientability, differentiable structure and metric structure. - Students learn the Gauss map and its many important consequences. - Students learn computations of various curvatures through examples and special surfaces.
syllabus: Topics include: regular curves, Frenet formulas, local theory of curves, global properties of curves such as isoperimetric inequality, regular surfaces, 1st and 2nd fundamental form, Gaussian curvature and mean curvature, Gauss map, special surfaces such as ruled surfaces, surfaces of revolution, minimal surfaces, intrinsic geometry: geodesics and Gauss-Bonnet Theorem.
recommended_readings: References: - M.P. do Carmo, Differential Geometry of Curves and Surfaces, Prentice Hall - B. O’Neill, Elementary Differential Geometry, Academic Press - J.J. Stoker, Differential Geometry, Wiley - J. Opera, Differential Geometry and Its Applications, 2nd Edition, Pearson

title: Real Analysis
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH2050/2058.
description: This is an introductory course on the Lebesgue integration theory on real line. Topics include: measurable sets, measurable functions, Lebesgue integral, Fatou's lemma, monotone convergence theorem, Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem and differentiation. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: - Students learn the basic properties of measurable sets and measurable functions on the real line. - Students learn the introduction of Lebesgue integration and its basic properties. - Students learn the fundamental convergence theorems including Fatou's lemma, monotone convergence theorem, Lebesgue dominate convergence theorem and results in connection with differentiation.
syllabus: Topics include: measurable sets, measurable functions, Lebesgue integral, Fatou’s lemma, monotone convergence theorem, Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem and differentiation. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis.

title: Complex Analysis

description: This course is designed for students who are intending to acquire advanced theoretical understanding about analytic functions, which is typically needed for further studies. The course emphasizes the rigorous treatment of the analysis of complex functions. Students are expected to have sophisticated mathematics background and superb theoretical knowledge in multivariable calculus. Major topics include entire functions of infinite series and infinite products, normal families, theory of conformal mappings. Details are given in course syllabus.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Modules and Representation Theory
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH3030.
description: This course is an introduction to modules over rings, as well as the representation theory of finite groups. It is one of the continuations of MATH3030 (the other being MATH3040). Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2070/2078 and MATH3030, or equivalent.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: We introduce the students to the advanced level of abstract algebra so that they are able to appreciate the exciting development of abstract algebra since the mid 19th century. And we provide the students with a solid background to understand deep mathematics and make them well-prepared for more advanced topics like: number theory, representation theory, algebraic geometry. Upon completion of the course, students should be able to - learn the basics of module theory: basic structural theory of modules, modules over principal ideal domains; - learn the basics of representation theory: group representations and group rings, Maschke's theorem, character theory, constructions of representations; - apply basic results and techniques to solve problems in the theory and other related subjects - prepare for graduate studies in algebra-related subjects such as algebraic geometry, algebraic number theory and representation theory.
syllabus: Modules are to rings as vector spaces to fields, and they form a model for linear structures that occur all over mathematics. Topics include basic structural theory of modules, modules over principal ideal domains, group representations and group rings, Maschke's theorem, character theory, constructions of representations, etc.

title: Financial Mathematics
description: Topics of this course will include: Basic option theory, forward and futures contracts, model of asset price, Ito's Lemma, asset price random walk, Black-Scholes model, free boundary problems of options, constrained matrix problems and the projected SOR method, discrete random walk model and the binomial methods. title: Partial Differential Equations
description: This is an introduction to the classical theory of partial differential equations. Topics are usually selected from: First-order equations, types of second-order equations, well-posedness of the wave and the heat equations, boundary value problems for the Laplace and Poisson equations, separation of variables. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: In general, the goal is to let the student understand the basic properties of the three principal types- hyperbolic, elliptic and parabolic equations. After taking and passing this course, a student is expected - to distinguish the types of the equations and use change of variables to simplify them,  - to solve well-posed problems by the method of separation of variables. (In particular, he/she should be able to use this method to solve the mixed problems including one-dimensional wave and heat equations as well as the boundary value problems for the Laplace equation on a disk.) - on the theoretical side, to know how the method of separation of variables is related to eigenvalue problems. (Rigorous proofs of convergence of the series of solutions should also be understood.) - to learn well the solution of the Cauchy problem for the wave equations in low dimensions by the method of spherical means, - to learn well the solution of the Cauchy problem for the heat equation by the heat kernel or by Fourier transform. The characteristic properties of heat flows and wave motions should be well-understood. - to know the Poison formula for the solution of the Laplace equation on a ball and have some idea of solving the problem over a general domain by Perron’s method, and  - to understand well various maximum principle as they are applied to the uniqueness issues for elliptic and parabolic equations.
syllabus: Topics are usually selected from: First-order equations, types of second-order equations, well-posedness of the wave and the heat equations, boundary value problems for the Laplace and Poisson equations, separation of variables.
recommended_readings: References (The first one is the main reference.) - Partial Differential Equations An introduction, by W.A. Strauss, John-Wiley & Sons, New York. (Easy to read. Contain many standard materials and exercises.) - A First Course in Partial Differential Equations with Complex and Transform Methods, by H. Weinberger, Dover Books on Mathematics. (This book is good source on separation of variables. Many work-out examples.) - Partial Differential Equations, 4th ed. by F. John, Springer-Verlag, New York. (A classic by a master. But a little bit difficult to read.) - Partial Differential Equations, by L.C. Evans, vol 19, Graduate Studies in Mathematics, American Mathematical Society, Providence. (Containing both linear and nonlinear theories, this is by far the best introductory book on PDE’s in postgraduate level. All proofs are rigorous and complete. The first several chapters can be read for good students in this class.)

title: Optimization Theory
description: Unconstrained and equality optimization models, constrained problems, optimality conditions for constrained extrema, convex sets and functions, duality in nonlinear convex programming, descent methods, conjugate direction methods and quasi-Newton methods. title: Advanced Numerical Analysis I
requirements: For MPhil-PhD Mathematics. Approval is needed for students in BSc Mathematics, BEd Mathematics and Mathematics Education or BSc Mathematics and Information Engineering.
description: This course covers basic numerical methods in the graduate level. The main themes are numerical solutions of PDEs and iterative methods for linear systems. For numerical solutions of PDEs, some basic theories of finite element methods for elliptic and parabolic equations are discussed. The topics include Sobolev spaces, embedding and trace theorems, variational formulation, Lax-Milgram theorem, finite element spaces and their interpolation theories, convergence in H1 and L2 norms. For iterative methods for linear systems, the topics include Richardson, Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and SOR methods, Krylov subspace methods, conjugate gradient method, preconditioning techniques, convergence theories, GMRES method.
outcome: Students are expected to learn the basic theories of finite element method for PDE and some classical iterative methods for linear algebraic and eigenvalue problems. The learning outcomes are - Students learn some theories of Sobolev spaces. - Students learn some embedding and trace theorems. - Students learn how to derive the variational formulation of PDE. - Students learn how to prove existence and uniqueness of variational problems by the use of Lax-Milgram theorem. - Students learn how to construct finite element spaces and obtain the corresponding interpolation error estimates. - Students learn how to prove convergence of finite element methods in H1 and L2 norms. - Students learn some basic iterative methods including Richardson, Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and SOR methods, and their convergence theories.  - Students learn Krylov subspace methods. - Students learn the conjugate gradient method and its convergence theory. - Students learn some preconditioning techniques for iterative methods. - Students learn the GMRES method and its convergence theory.
syllabus: The topics include Sobolev spaces, embedding and trace theorems, variational formulation, Lax-Milgram theorem, finite element spaces and their interpolation theories, convergence in H1 and L2 norms. For iterative methods for linear systems, the topics include Richardson, Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and SOR methods, Krylov subspace methods, conjugate gradient method, preconditioning techniques, convergence theories, GMRES method.
